details.description: The resource that is referenced by a particular "about" URI is denoted by the <about-token> part of the URI.
The CAP URL scheme is used to designate both calendar stores and calendars accessible using the CAP protocol.
Some applications that use URLs also have a need to embed (small) media type data directly inline. This document defines a new URL scheme that would work like 'immediate addressing'.
A DNS URI designates a DNS resource record set, referenced by domain name, class, type, and, optionally, the authority.

There is a need for a scheme name that can be used for examples in documentation without fear of conflicts with current or future actual schemes. The scheme "example" is hereby registered as a 'permanent' scheme for that purpose.
The FTP URL scheme is used to designate files and directories on Internet hosts accessible using the FTP protocol.

The 'geo' URI scheme provides the textual representation of the location's spatial coordinates in either two or three dimensions (latitude, longitude, and optionally altitude for the default CRS of WGS-84).

The "http" URI scheme is hereby defined for the purpose of minting identifiers according to their association with the hierarchical namespace governed by a potential HTTP origin server listening for TCP connections on a given port.

The "https" URI scheme is hereby defined for the purpose of minting identifiers according to their association with the hierarchical namespace governed by a potential HTTP origin server listening to a given TCP port for TLS-secured connections.

Use of the im: URI follows closely usage of the mailto: URI. That is, invocation of an IM URI will cause the user's instant messaging application to start, with destination address and message headers fill-in according to the information supplied in the URI.

This document defines the "info" Uniform Resource Identifier (URI) scheme for information assets that have identifiers in public namespaces but are not part of the URI allocation. By "information asset" this document intends any information construct that has identity within a public namespace.
A 'mailto' URI designates an "Internet resource", which is the mailbox specified in the address.

A Named Identifier can be represented using the ni URI scheme that we specifically define for the name. However it is represented, the Named Identifier *names* a resource, and the mechanism used to dereference the name and to *locate* the named resource needs to be known by the entity that dereferences it.
Fields in nih URIs are separated by a semicolon (;) character. The first field is a hash algorithm string, as in the ni URI format.
The URI scheme defined in this document is designed specifically with a mapping to the PKCS #11 API in mind.

Use of the pres: URI follows closely usage of the mailto: URI. That is, invocation of an PRES URI will cause the user's instant messaging application to start, with destination address and message headers  fill-in according to the information supplied in the URI.
This section describes the scheme for a reload URI, which can be used to refer to either a peer (e.g., as used in a certificate), or a resource inside a peer.

The URI is intended to identify a data resource previously given to the network computing resource. The purpose of this scheme is to permit access to the specific resource for the lifetime of the session with the entity storing the resource.

This URI scheme provides information that can be used for sending SMS message(s) to specified recipient(s). The functionality is comparable to that of the "mailto" URI, which can also be used with a comma-separated list of email addresses.
The Telnet URL scheme is used to designate interactive services that may be accessed by the Telnet protocol.
The only operation for this scheme is to open a connection using the WebSocket Protocol.
The only operation for this scheme is to open a connection using the WebSocket Protocol, encrypted using TLS.
